raw_text:
Kerr frustrated at victory margin
 
 Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr admitted he was frustrated his side did not score more than one goal in their friendly win over Croatia.
 
 Robbie Keane took his Republic record to 24 with a first-half goal which proved enough for victory. "We had more good chances. It is just a shame we did not take them against such a technically gifted team," said Kerr. "But, given the conditions and the standard of the Croatian team, we should be very happy with the win." The Republic side kept a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and are unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr succeeded Mick McCarthy. Kerr applauded the decisive move which earned the victory. "It was a brilliant goal, fantastic skill by Damien Duff. Robbie might have scuffed it a little but it was a good goal." Matchwinner Keane was another full of praise for Duff's role in the goal. "It was great play from Damien," said the Tottenham striker.
 
 "I always try to be sniffing around because you know nine times out of 10 Duffer is going to get it in the box. "Playing three up was something different. Brian Kerr wanted to try it out and it was good to see young Stephen Elliott getting a run-out. "The conditions were difficult but he did well and is definitely one for the future. It is nice to see young players coming through." Man-of-the-match Duff explained what went wrong when he fluffed a chance to make it 2-0 midway through the second half. He opted to bring Steve Finnan's cross down and shoot against the bar when a close-range header looked the best option. "I would have headed that every time but I completely lost it in the lights," said the Chelsea star. "I was desperate to get on the scoresheet myself but the result is the important thing. "We have had a good year and are going nicely in the qualifiers. Hopefully that can continue in 2005."
llama3.2:1b: Brian Kerr admitted he was frustrated with his side's lack of goals, despite Robbie Keane's first-half goal giving them an 8-0 win over Croatia.
The Republic team kept their clean sheet record intact for the eighth time and are unbeaten at home since Kerry took over as manager.
Robbie Keane praised Damien Duff's role in the match-winning goal, while Kerr commended the team's decision to play three up.
llama3.2:3b: Brian Kerr expressed frustration at Republic of Ireland's limited goal-scoring despite victory over Croatia, citing missed chances.
Robbie Keane scored once in the first half to seal the win.
Damien Duff set up Keane with a brilliant goal, and praised Duff for his skill and play.
gemma2:2b: Ireland manager Brian Kerr expressed frustration at not scoring more against Croatia, but praised his team's victory.
Robbie Keane scored the only goal for Ireland, which was achieved thanks to Damien Duff's skillful play.
Young Stephen Elliott also impressed in a test of different tactics.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Brian Kerr praised his side's performance during their friendly match with Croatia, where they won by one goal.
Robbie Keane scored the winning goal with a first-half assist.
The Republic of Ireland maintained a clean sheet for the eighth time and are unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr succeeded Mick McCarthy.
Manager Brian Kerr was impressed with Keane's play during the game, describing him as "great play from Damien."
The team expressed their satisfaction with this victory while acknowledging that scoring more than one goal may not be ideal in football.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Brian Kerr, Ireland manager, frustrated by only one goal scored in friendly match against Croatia; Robbie Keane praised Damien Duff's goal for winning; Ireland kept clean sheet, unbeaten at home games since coach change; Stephen Elliott praised for debut performance under new coach.
qwen2.5:3b: Kerr expresses frustration over Republic of Ireland's narrow victory against Croatia, citing missed chances.
Robbie Keane scored twice, earning his record fourth goal for the national team.
Kerr praises Damien Duff’s goal and Stephen Elliott’s debut performance.
Duff admits to missing a header in the second half; he attributes it to poor lighting conditions rather than poor technique.
The Irish side maintains an unbeaten record with eight clean sheets in 11 matches, thanks to Kerr's tactical experimentation.
opencoder:1.5b: Kerr frustrated at victory margin.
The Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr admitted he was frustrated his side did not score more than one goal in their friendly win over Croatia.
Robbie Keane took his Republic record to 24 with a first-half goal which proved enough for victory.
"We had more good chances.
It is just a shame we did not take them against such a technically gifted team," said Kerr.
"But, given the conditions and the standard of the Croatian team, we should be very happy with the win."
The Republic side kept a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and are unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr succeeded Mick McCarthy.
Kerr applauded the decisive move which earned the victory.
"It was a brilliant goal, fantastic skill by Damien Duff.
Robbie might have scuffed it a little bit but it was a good goal."
Matchwinner Keane was another full of praise for Duff's role in the goal.
"It was great play from Damien," said the Tottenham striker.
He always try to be sniffing around because you know nine times out of 10 Duff is going to get it in the box.
"Playing three up was something different.
Brian Kerr wanted to try it out and it was good to see young Stephen Elliott getting a run-out.
The conditions were difficult but he did well and is definitely one for the future.
It is nice to see young players coming through."
Man-of-the-match Duff explained what went wrong when he fluffed a chance to make it 2-0 midway through the second half.
He opted to bring Steve Finnan's cross down and shoot against the bar when a close-range header looked the best option.
"I would have gone that every time but I completely lost it in the lights," said the Chelsea star.
"I was so desperate to get on the scoresheet myself but the result is the important thing.
We have had a good year and are going nicely in the qualifiers.
Hopefully that can continue in 2005."

"But, given the conditions and the standard of the Croatian team, we should be very happy with the win."
The Republic side kept a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and are unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr succeeded Mick McCarthy.
Kerr applauded the decisive move which earned the victory.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Kerr was frustrated by his side scoring only one goal in a friendly match against Croatia, while Robbie scored the first goal.
Kerr praised Robbie's contribution but acknowledged a technical challenge.
The Republic ended with eight clean sheets and is unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr took over.
Kerr commended Robbie for a decisive win and highlighted his team's solid record.
Keane praised Duff's performance, and Kerr discussed conditions favoring the team while showing growth.

tinyllama:1.1b: Brian Kerr was disappointed with his team's lack of goals in their friendly match against Croatia.
Despite making three changes from their previous match, they could only score once and concede in the final stages to lose 1-0.
However, Kerr praised Robbie Keane's crucial goal and believed that the team played well despite the challenging conditions and technical abilities of their opponents.
Despite losing the match, Kerr highlighted Damien Duff as a standout player for his role in scoring the decisive goal.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Kerr frustrated at victory margin Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr admitted he was frustrated his side did not score more than one goal in their friendly win over Croatia.
Kerr, who is currently managing the team for the third time since being appointed in 2001, said it is a shame that they didn't take more chances against such a technically gifted team.
The Republic of Ireland defeated Croatia 2-0 on Friday, with Robbie Keane scoring their only goal and Robbie McDonald getting an assist.
Kerr praised Damien Duff for his skillful goal, which came after successful passes from his teammates.
He also commended Stephen Elliott for making his first appearance in the match.

The conditions were challenging, but Duff made a great play to score, and the Republic of Ireland kept a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and are unbeaten at home since Kerr succeeded Mick McCarthy.
Duff was pleased with his performance, calling it "a brilliant goal" and crediting Damien Duff's skillful play for getting him on the scoresheet.
phi:2.7b: Ireland won their friendly match against Croatia with Robbie Keane scoring 24 goals for his team, while Brian Kerr was frustrated by not being able to score more than one goal.
The Republic of Ireland's clean sheet record was improved upon, and Damien Duff received praise from the manager for his goal-scoring skills.
Mick Rooney also acknowledged Duff's role in the win.
While Robbie Keane and Steve Finnan were commended for their performances, Stephen Elliott made a strong debut by getting a run-out.
Although Duff missed a golden opportunity to score again, he was content with the result.
The team is hoping that this success will continue into future matches.
orca-mini:3b: Brian Kerr expressed frustration at his side's lack of scoring more than one goal in their friendly win over Croatia.
Robbie Keane scored a first-half goal which proved to be the winner.
The Republic side kept a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches and are unbeaten in 14 home games since Kerr took charge.
Damien Duff's decisive move was praised by both players involved.
Brian Kerr wanted to try a three-man defense, which included young Stephen Elliott, and it worked well with Damien Duff scoring twice.
Robbie Keane praised Damien Duff for his role in the goal, but admitted he made a mistake when he fluffed a chance to make it 2-0 midway through the second half.
The result was important, and the Republic are on track in their World Cup qualifiers.
hermes3:3b: Kerr disapproves of low goal score in Ireland's win over Croatia, happy with victory despite missed chances; praises Damien Duff for decisive move.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr expressed frustration over his team's single goal performance in their friendly win against Croatia.
Robbie Keane scored the only goal, tying the record with 24 goals.
Kerr praised Damien Duff's role in the goal and acknowledged the impact of young players like Stephen Elliott.

Despite Duff's misspelled chance midway through the second half, he expressed satisfaction with his team's overall performance, noting their success in qualifiers and hopes for future successes in 2005.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr was frustrated that his team did not score more than one goal in their friendly win over Croatia, despite creating good chances.
Robbie Keane's first-half goal, set up by Damien Duff, secured the victory.
Kerr praised Duff's skill and acknowledged the tough conditions and Croatia's quality.
The Republic maintained a strong defensive record, keeping a clean sheet for the eighth time in 11 matches.
Keane and Duff both highlighted Duff's contribution, while Keane noted the effectiveness of playing three forwards and praised young player Stephen Elliott.
Duff admitted missing a chance to make it 2-0 due to losing sight of the ball in the lights but emphasized the importance of the win.
He expressed optimism about the team's progress in the qualifiers.
stablelm2:1.6b: Republic of Ireland manager Brian Kerr expresses frustration over his side not scoring more against Croatia, as Robbie Keane's first-half goal leads to a 1-0 victory.
Republic side maintains its unbeaten streak since replacing Mick McCarthy with an eight-game winning streak and clean sheet.
Damien Duff's goal is praised for being a brilliant play by Duff.
Stephen Elliott also receives recognition after his run-out in the game, which was played under challenging conditions.
Steve Finnan's cross results in a missed opportunity that leads to Duff's eventual goal.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Brian Kerr, Republic of Ireland manager, expressed frustration over his team's limited goal tally, despite their 1-0 victory over Croatia in a friendly match.
Striker Robbie Keane scored the only goal with a well-executed first-half play, highlighting Damien Duff's excellent skill.
Kerr praised the team's defensive performance, noting they maintained an eighth clean sheet in 11 matches and remained unbeaten in 14 home games since his appointment.
Keane commended Duff for his exceptional play leading to the goal, while Duff himself admitted a missed opportunity midway through the second half due to poor decision-making under lights.
Despite the slight disappointment, Kerr emphasized the team's overall positive progress in qualifiers, hoping for continued success in 2005.
